items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Revised board policy 2735 (formerly 2620) regarding Board of Trustees travel was presented for first reading at the July 7, 2014, meeting.  The proposed revision updates language to reflect recommendations from the February 3, 2014, Board of Trustees study session discussion of professional development, adds a reference to a related administrative procedure, and changes the policy number to match the Community College League of California's Policy and Procedure Service numbering system. Added language is indicated on the attachment by bold, underlined text, while deleted text is represented by strikethrough. 
	 
The revised policy was approved by the Chancellor's Advisory Council electronically on March 14, 2014.
	 
References:
Education Code Section 72423
	 
Submitted by:
Linda Thor
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The District owns miscellaneous surplus property (see attached) that is not satisfactory for further use by the District.  California Education Code sections 81450 – 81452 provides that the governing board of a community college district may sell, donate, or dispose of personal property if it is unsatisfactory and no longer suitable for school use. The estimated aggregate resale value is greater than $5,000.00.
 
District staff will assess and identify the most efficient manner to disposition the surplus that is in the best interest of the District and in accordance with California Education Code.
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director, Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Eric Olague, Buyer, Purchasing Services
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Authorize the Director of Purchasing Services to arrange for the sale, donation, recycle, or disposal of the surplus in accordance with the procedures set forth in Education Code sections 81450-81452.
items.item_text: Sell, Donate, Recycle, or Dispose of District Surplus
items.item_text_raw: 7. Sell, Donate, Recycle, or Dispose of District Surplus

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The District has eight pallets of computers, monitors, printers, and miscellaneous electronic equipment (see attached).  The District’s Educational Technology Services Department (ETS) staff has determined that the items are obsolete and of no further use to the District.  In accordance with the Electronic Waste Recycling Act these items are considered electronic waste. The estimated aggregate market value of this electronic equipment is less than $5,000.00.
	 
California Education Code 81452(a) provides that if the governing board by a unanimous vote of those members present, finds that the property, whether one or more items, does not exceed in value the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), the property may be sold by any employee of the District empowered for that purpose by the board. 
	 
Purchasing Services will post a notice on Bid Net and call for competitive bids from authorized State of California material handlers, collectors, and recyclers.  Proceeds will be deposited to the District’s general fund.
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director, Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Eric Olague, Buyer, Purchasing Services
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Make a finding that the property does not exceed $5,000.00 in value and authorize the Director of Purchasing Services to sell the items in accordance with Education Code 81452(a).
items.item_text: Sale of Miscellaneous Surplus Electronic Equipment
items.item_text_raw: 8. Sale of Miscellaneous Surplus Electronic Equipment

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The district’s Parking and Traffic Regulations permit the Board of Trustees to approve a waiver or reduction of parking fees. Foothill College President Judy Miner requests that the following parking lot rental fees be waived because these events are internal and/or are hosted by organizations that support the college mission:
	 
Wednesday, September 17, 2014 – Foothill College Parking Lot 1 - $650.00
Foothill College will host the new student orientation on September 17, 2014 in the Smithwick Theatre for approximately 700 students. The Office of Student Affairs & Activities requests free parking in Lot 1 from 7:00 a.m. – 3:00 p.m.
	 
Friday, September 19, 2014 – Foothill College Parking Lot 1, 1H, 2A, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8 - $5,475.00
Foothill College will host the college’s Opening Day on September 19, 2014 in the Smithwick Theatre for all Foothill employees. The President’s requests free parking in all lots from 7:00 a.m. – 4:00 p.m.
	 
Submitted by:
Judy C. Miner
Additional contact names:
Pat Hyland
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: Foothill College President Judy Miner recommends that the Board of Trustees waive the parking lot rental fees.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Happy Kids Day
Saturday, August 23, 2014 
10 a.m. to 5 p.m.
Parking Lots A, B, and C
	 
Happy Kids Day, held in Memorial Park, is a multicultural festival featuring activities, games and performances for children of all ages. Sponsored by the city of Cupertino, area nonprofits and regional businesses, it is one of the largest children’s events in the San Francisco Bay Area and a major event for the city.
	 
	 
Diwali Festival of Lights
Saturday, September 27, 2014
10 am to 5 pm
Parking Lots A and B
	 
The Cupertino Chamber of Commerce and its Asian American Business Council (AABC) host the annual Diwali Festival of Lights. This event brings more than 12,000 people to Memorial Park in Cupertino and is a showcase of multicultural music, dance, workshops, arts and crafts, and food.
	 
De Anza College President Brian Murphy requests that the board approve the waiver of parking fees for these two major community events.
	 
Submitted by:
  De Anza College President, Brian Murphy, ext 8706
Additional contact names:
  Director of Marketing, Communications & Development, Marisa Spatafore, ext 8672
Is backup provided?
  no
items.item_recommendation: De Anza College President, Brian Murphy recommends board approval of the waiver of parking fees for two major community events.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The district's Occupational Training Institute (OTI) will provide an array of education, training and job placement services for CalWORKs clients. Foothill-De Anza Community College District will provide site liaisons at designated campuses. Site liaisons will work collaboratively with CalWORKs staff and each other to enroll students in the first class opening and minimize time on wait lists. Site Liaisons will provide supportive services, family stabilization services, case tracking and client progress reporting an accordance with CalWORKs employment services rules and regulations. The total amount of this contract will not exceed $122,722 in grant funding.
	 
Board approval is requested for the renewal of this CalWORKs liaison contract for the 2014-15 year.
	 
Submitted by:

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
During California's economic downturn, the Board of Governors of the California Community Colleges enacted regulations to limit the repeatability of coursework in order to prioritize basic skills, career technical education, and transfer preparation over lifelong learning. The changes were made in light of severe year-over-year reductions in state funding combined with increased enrollment demands fueled in part by high unemployment rates. 
	 
The repeatability limits, change in state priorities, and workload reduction forced the colleges to make program adjustments that have negatively impacted district enrollment and reduced opportunities previously available to students in performance and skill-building courses as well as lifelong learners in the community.
	 
The attached resolution, which was discussed and amended at the July 7, 2014, regular meeting of the Board of Trustees, would urge the Board of Governors to adjust repeatability regulations to take into account the needs of students taking courses outside the state prioritized areas of basic skills, career technical education, and transfer preparation.
	 
Submitted by:
Linda Thor
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
Yes (Replacement repeatability resolution (revision 2) posted 7/31/14)
items.item_recommendation: Chancellor Linda Thor recommends adoption of resolution number 2014-19 in support of changes to community college repeatability regulations.
items.item_text: Resolution in Support of Changes to Community College Repeatability Regulations (ACTION)
items.item_text_raw: 17. Resolution in Support of Changes to Community College Repeatability Regulations (ACTION)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Students involved in De Anza College's Public Policy School working in conjunction with Evolve, a San Francisco-based community organization, have advocated at recent meetings for governing board support of a resolution endorsing a change to Proposition 13 to modify the method by which commercial properties are assessed in order to increase funding for public schools. 
	 
Proposition 13 limits the property tax rate to one percent of the assessed value of a home at the time of purchase and holds annual tax increases to no more than two percent until the property is sold. Under Proposition 13, industrial, commercial, and residential property are treated the same. When Proposition 13 passed in 1978, 40 percent of property taxes in California were paid by commercial property owners, but that percentage has been reduced to 28 percent over time. Evolve estimates that an additional $6 billion per year would be available to fund public schools and services if the proposal to reassess commercial properties more often were enacted.
	 
At the July 7, 2014, regular meeting of the Board of Trustees, a resolution drafted by Evolve was presented for discussion. According to Evolve's web site, four community college districts have adopted resolutions supporting the effort as have a number of K-12 school districts and city councils. The governing board expressed general support for Proposition 13 reform but expressed concern regarding some of the assertions made in the resolution. Board members also questioned whether community colleges would benefit from reform or if additional property tax income generated would be offset by Proposition 98.  Trustees Barram and Casas agreed to revise the resolution based on feedback received at the meeting.  The revised draft is attached for the governing board's consideration.
	 
Submitted by:
Linda Thor
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Chancellor Linda Thor recommends adoption of the resolution in support of Proposition 13 reform.
items.item_text: Resolution in Support of Proposition 13 Reform (ACTION)
items.item_text_raw: 18. Resolution in Support of Proposition 13 Reform (ACTION)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Revised board policy 2712 (formerly 9200) Conflict of Interest Code is attached for first reading. Under the Political Reform Act, the district is required to review its conflict of interest code every even-numbered year, and policy amendments must be approved both by the district's Board of Trustees and the Santa Clara County Board of Supervisors. Revisions to the policy language were recommended by the Santa Clara Office of the County Counsel to clarify disclosure requirements and ensure compliance with recent decisions by the Fair Political Practices Commission. In addition, the policy has been updated to reflect position title changes as well as new positions created in connection with the Online Education Initiative grant. 
	 
The Santa Clara County Counsel's office has provided preliminary approval of the proposed amended code, and it was approved electronically by the Chancellor's Advisory Council on July 25, 2014. The revised policy will be presented for governing board approval at the August 25, 2014, meeting.
	 
Submitted by:
Linda Thor
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
Yes

Additional geotechnical services required by California Geological Survey, whose approval is required by Division of the State Architect, including additional subsurface investigation of areas that were inaccessible at the time of the original study, and updating the geotechnical report to the new building code.
	 
Funding for this change is included in the project budget.
	 
Submitted by:
Art Heinrich, Interim Executive Director, Facilities and Operations

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
This revision is required to implement Bond list changes that are needed to adjust and prioritize approved project scopes and funding at Foothill, District/Central Services and De Anza College.  
	 
De Anza Budget Transfer #45 includes the following actions:
Transfer $3,777.62 project savings from Project 214, Corporation Yard to Project 225, Campus Wide Electronic Locks to fund the project. Project 214 is financially complete.
Transfer $200,000 from Project 245, ATC to Project 229, Environmental Studies Area to fund the project. 
Transfer $50,000 from Project 245, ATC to Project 225, Campus Wide Electronic Locks to fund the project.
Transfer $50,000 from Project 299, De Anza Program Contingency to Project 225, Campus Wide Electronic Locks to fund the project
Transfer $14,337 from Project 252, Elevator Upgrades – Campus Wide to Project 248, Campus Drive and $6,360.08 to Project 225, Campus Wide Electronic Locks to fund the projects. Project 252 is financially complete.
Note that current budget for Project 251, Install Photovoltaics (251C) will have additional funding source of $89,861.60 due to PG&E Rebates (Checks 47-48 Series 1 and Checks 26-27 Series 2) not shown here.
Note that $44,930 from Campus Center Fee fund will be recognized by 261 Project, MLC for Campus Center’s portion of the Curb Cut and Fence Project.
	 
Foothill Budget Transfer #47 includes the following actions:
Transfer $187,595 from Project 111, Swing Space to Project 121, Library & ISC to fund library stack shelving.
Transfer $150,000 from Project 100, Scheduled Maintenance to Project 174, Fire Alarm System Replacement Phase III to fund the project.
Note that $187,433 from FY13-14 State Scheduled Maintenance will be recognized by Project 105, Modernization of Learning Support Center, Biology and General for the S J Amoroso contract.
	 
District/Central Services Project Name Change:
Rename Project 801, Property Acquisition to Foothill-DeAnza Education Center. The new project description is: Provide instructional facilities, classrooms and lecture rooms, administrative offices and support space at the Foothill-DeAnza Education Center, to be located on Innovation Way in Sunnyvale, CA.
	 
Submitted by:
Art Heinrich
Additional contact names:
Bernata Slater, Tom Armstrong and Donna Jones-Dulin
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Art Heinrich, Interim Executive Director of Facilities and Operations recommends that the Board approve the Bond Project List Revision with Foothill Budget Transfer #47 and De Anza Budget Transfer #45.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
This project will provide safety equipment systems in the twelve (12) mechanical shafts in the Media and Learning Center.  The shafts will be installed with cable ladder safety equipment at the platforms and ladders; the service platforms will be installed with toe kicks and gates for worker safety and protection. Additionally, safety equipment will be installed to protect workers while maintaining equipment on the rooftop.  Ratcliff Architects prepared the bid specifications for the work.
	 
The bid was legally advertised to contractors on April 16, April 23, June 6, and June 13, 2014. The “Invitation to Bid” was also sent to nine (9) builder’s exchanges and advertised in the Daily Pacific Builder as well as posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  Bids were publicly opened and read on July 16, 2014 in the Purchasing Services office. Two (2) contractors submitted bids. Bid results are below:
BID RESULTS
Contractor
Base Bid 
Proposal Amount
Rodan Builders Inc.
$127,500
Southwest Construction & Property Management
$144,000
	 
The apparent low bidder, Rodan Builders, Inc. has confirmed that its bid price of $127,500 is true and accurate for the work as specified. Rodan Builders, Inc. has successfully completed projects for San Francisco State University and San Mateo Union High School District and was recently awarded the contract for the tennis court resurfacing project at Foothill College.
	 
The construction estimate is $150,000 and the budget for the project is $130,000. The bid price of $127,400 is well within the budget and will be paid for with Measure C funds.
	 
Submitted by:
  Director of Purchasing Services, Pam Grey
Additional contact names:
  Art Heinrich, Tom Armstrong, Gina Bailey
Is backup provided?
items.item_recommendation: Authorize the Director of Purchasing Services, Pam Grey, to award a contract pursuant to Bid Document 1682-261, Shaft Safety & Guardrails Project – Media and Learning Center, De Anza College in the amount of $127,400 to Rodan Builders, Inc.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
This project will complete the upgrades to the campus-wide fire alarm and monitoring system to be compliant with current building codes as required by the Division of the State Architect.  Work will include upgrades of the existing Siemen fire alarm control units, upgrading the campus graphic annunciator, new fiber optic cabling, programming, and testing. Phase I of the project was constructed under Measure E and Phase II was constructed under Measure C in 2008/2009. Rolf Jensen and Associates prepared the bid specifications for the work in Phase III.
	 
The bid was legally advertised to contractors on May 14, May 21, June 4, and June 11, 2014. The “Invitation to Bid” was also sent to nine (9) builder’s exchanges and advertised in the Daily Pacific Builder as well as posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  Bids were publicly opened and read on July 10, 2014 in the Purchasing Services office. Two (2) contractors submitted bids. Bid results are below:
BID RESULTS
Contractor
Base Bid 
Proposal Amount
Cupertino Electric, Inc.
$ 885,009
Rodan Builders Inc.
$1,049,000
	 
The apparent low bidder, Cupertino Electric, Inc. has confirmed that its bid price of $885,009 is true and accurate for the work as specified. Furthermore, Cupertino Electric, Inc. has signed the “Agreement To Be Bound” of the Project Stabilization/Construction Careers Agreement between the District and the Santa Clara & San Benito Counties Building and Construction Trades Council.  Cupertino Electric, Inc. has successfully performed subcontract work for the District, including the electrical scope of the Measure C Central Campus Site Improvements project and electrical decommissioning and demolition of Onizuka Air Force Station. Cupertino Electric, Inc. also completed fire alarm upgrade projects for Mt. View High School and Los Altos High School in 2011.
	 
The engineer’s estimate for the project is $670,000 and the Measure C budget is $622,196.  Bids received were higher than the construction estimate primarily due to current market conditions for this type of work and the difficulty of construction in the utility tunnels between occupied buildings; a majority of the work will be performed as premium shift work, either in the evenings or on weekends.  Rebidding the project is not likely to result in a cost savings; rather costs may likely increase due to the improvements in the economy.  To fully fund the project, Measure C budget transfer  #47 will increase the project budget by $150,000 and the budget will be further augmented with State scheduled maintenance funds.
	 
Submitted by:
  Director of Purchasing, Pam Grey
Additional contact names:
  Art Heinrich, Roseanne Sciacchitano, Gina Bailey
Is backup provided?
  No
items.item_recommendation: Authorize the Director of Purchasing Services, Pam Grey, to award a contract pursuant to Bid Document 1647-174, Fire Alarm System Replacement Phase III at Foothill College in the amount of $885,009 to Cupertino Electric, Inc

items.item_text_raw: 29. Award a contract for Bid Document 1647-174, Fire Alarm System Replacement Phase III, Foothill College - $885,009 (ACTION)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
At its March 3, 2014 meeting, the Board of Trustees accepted a list of eight (8) contractors who met all of the prequalification requirements as the only prime contractors who were “prequalified” to bid on the De Anza College Measure C Project #216 – Library.  
	 
The De Anza Library renovation project consists of minor exterior civil work at northeast, north and northwest patio areas including new stairs, railings, pavement replacement plus new benches; building structural work includes interior shotcrete walls and minor concrete and steel floor infill; seismic bracing of existing and various book shelf stacks; interior and exterior lighting replacement including lighting control panel; fire alarm replacement including main panel; HVAC improvements including duct cleaning, replacement of HVAC mechanical systems and new Building Management System (BMS) controls; (1) elevator removal and (1) elevator renovation; reconfigure spaces including work areas, circulation spaces and study rooms; new painting inside and outside and new floor finishes; bathroom renovations; flat roof replacement, tile roof removal and replacement after new waterproof membrane is installed, and replacement of all roofing-related sheet metal; minor ADA ramp access work at the main entry on the east side.  The work for Alternate 1 includes colored concrete paving, Alternate 3 includes fire alarm replacement at Learning Center West, and Alternate 4 includes new light fixtures in Room 110A, 126A, and 128.  
	 
Noll and Tam Architects prepared the construction documents and a complete set of all bid documents are on file in the Purchasing Services Department. 
	 
Bid #1692-216 was legally advertised to contractors June 5, 2014, and June 12, 2014.  The Invitation to Bid was also sent to nine (9) builders’ exchanges, advertised in the San Jose Post Record, and posted on BidNet at www.govbids.com.  A mandatory bid walk was held on June 18, 2014, and a total of seven (7) prequalified contractors attended the walk.  Bids were publicly opened and read on July 17, 2014 by Purchasing Services.  Six (6) contractors submitted a bid and the bid results are summarized below:

The apparent lowest responsive and responsible bidder was D.L. Falk Construction, Inc. Furthermore, D.L. Falk Construction Inc. and its listed subcontractors have each signed the “Agreement To Be Bound” and the “Agreement of Contractors” of the Project Stabilization/Construction Careers Agreement between the District and the Santa Clara & San Benito Counties Building and Construction Trades Council.  
	 
The bid price of $7,402,000 (base bid + alternate 1, 3, and 4) submitted by D.L. Falk Construction, Inc. is within the architect’s estimate of $8,500,000 and the overall project budget of $9,760,000.  Therefore, the Measure C Bond team recommends award of a contract for the base bid proposal amount plus Alternates 1, 3, and 4 to D.L. Falk Construction, Inc.  
	 
This project is funded by Measure C. 
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Art Heinrich, Tom Armstrong, Annette Perez
Is backup provided?
No

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
This is a rebid of a project for the renovation and repair of the existing Environmental Studies Area (ESA) pond including a new liner, a new root-barrier system, mechanical/electrical renovations to support the pond infrastructure, and ADA compliant pathways.  The Environmental Studies program primarily uses the ESA as an outdoor classroom laboratory.  The ecosystem within the pond and creek is an essential element in the program curriculum.  Joni L. Janecki Associates prepared the final bid specifications for the work.  A complete set of all bid documents are on file in the Purchasing Services Department. 
	 
The bid was legally advertised to contractors on June 10 and June 17, 2014.  The “Invitation to Bid” was also sent to nine (9) builders’ exchanges, advertised in the San Jose Post Record, and posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  A mandatory bid walk was held on June 24, 2014, and a total of nine (9) potential contractors attended the walk.  Bids were publicly opened and read on July 16, 2014 by Purchasing Services.  One contractor submitted a bid and the bid result is summarized below:
BID RESULTS
	 
Contractor
Base Bid Proposal Amount:
Guerra Construction Group
$730,400
	 
Purchasing staff reached out to the eight (8) other contractors who attended the mandatory bid walk.  The general consensus is that the project is very challenging, additionally contractors in this field of work are overwhelmed with other less challenging projects and are bidding projects that are more attractive. Furthermore, it is not recommended that the bid be rejected and rebid at a later time. Previous attempts at awarding this project have been unsuccessful. Rebidding the project is not likely to result in a cost savings; rather staff is concerned that costs may likely continue to increase due to the improvements in the economy.  
	 
Guerra Construction Group (Guerra) has confirmed that its bid price is correct and accurate.  Furthermore, Guerra, and its listed subcontractors, have signed the “Agreement to be Bound” of the Project Stabilization/Construction Careers Agreement between the District and the Santa Clara & San Benito Counties Building Trades Council.  Guerra has recently completed campus improvements at De Anza College.
	 
The bid submitted by Guerra exceeds the landscape architect’s construction estimate and the construction budget of $390,000.  Therefore, the construction bond management team (Gilbane, purchasing staff, bond management, architect) met with Guerra to understand how its bid pricing was developed, to confirm that the scope of work was reflective of the bid specifications, to identify any site conditions that can be modified in efforts to reduce cost, and to identify any scopes of work that can be removed or altered to reduce the final costs of work.  Guerra shared that the site conditions are a primary reason for the cost for the work; there are several trees that require protection, work is limited to confined spaces that require smaller and slower equipment, there is an extensive amount of manual labor involved to perform the work, and there is no viable location for stockpiling of materials, dirt, etc. Therefore, through a process called “value engineering” the team and Guerra were able to identify potential savings in the aggregate amount of $143,000 by making the changes proposed below:
	 
Credit - $37,000 – increase the staging area
Credit - $38,000 – additional capacity for trucking needs
Credit - $23,000 – more accessibility
Credit - $36,000 – larger equipment in lieu of smaller
Credit - $15,000 – reduce irrigation handwork
Add - $6,000 – remove trees to provide access for large equipment
	 
In accordance with PCC 20651(b), the governing board shall let any contract for a public project to the lowest responsible bidder, or reject all bids.  Therefore, the award to Guerra must be authorized based upon its bid amount of $730,400.  However, after award, it is the Districts intent to revise the contract and issue deductive change orders in the aggregate amount of $143,000.  The project will be funded through De Anza College Measure C budget transfer #45 in addition to Measure C project funds.
	 
Submitted by:
  Director of Purchasing Services - Pam Grey
Additional contact names:
  Art Heinrich, Tom Armstrong, Donna Jones Dulin, Gina Bailey
Is backup provided?
items.item_recommendation: Authorize the Director of Purchasing Services, Pam Grey, to award a contract pursuant to Bid Document 1646-229R, Environmental Studies Area at De Anza College in the amount of $730,400 to Guerra Construction Group.
